journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of the American Heart Association: Cardiovascular and Cerebrovascular Disease

title-group.article-title: Durability of Benefits From Supervised Treadmill Exercise in People With Peripheral Artery Disease

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is nonâcommercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: It is currently unknown whether 6Â months of supervised treadmill exercise has a durable benefit on 6âminute walk performance, even after exercise is completed, in people with peripheral artery disease.

sec.title: Methods and Results
sec.p: A total of 156 participants with peripheral artery disease were randomized to 1 of 3 groups: supervised treadmill exercise, supervised resistance training, or attention control. Participants received supervised sessions during months 1 to 6 and telephone contact during months 6 to 12. Primary outcomes were change in 6âminute walk distance and short physical performance battery at 6âmonth followâup and have been reported previously. Secondary outcomes were change in 6âminute walk and short physical performance battery at 12âmonth followâup and are reported here. A group of 134 participants (86%) completed the 12âmonth followâup. At 6âmonth followâup, compared with control, 6âminute walk distance improved in the treadmill exercise group (+36.1Â m, 95% CI=13.9â58.3, P=0.001). Between 6â and 12âmonth followâup, 6âminute walk distance significantly declined (â28.6Â m, 95% CI=â52.6 to â4.5, P=0.020) and physical activity declined â272 activity units (95% CI=â546 to +2, P=0.052) in the treadmill exercise group compared with controls. At 12âmonth followâup, 6Â months after completing supervised treadmill exercise, change in 6âminute walk distance was not different between the treadmill exercise and control groups (+7.5, 95% CI=â17.5 to +32.6, P=0.56). There were no differences in short physical performance battery change between either exercise group and control at 6âmonth or 12âmonth followâup.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A 6âmonth supervised treadmill exercise intervention that improved 6âminute walk distance at 6âmonth followâup did not have persistent benefit at 12âmonth followâup. These results do not support a durable benefit of supervised treadmill exercise in peripheral artery disease.

sec.title: Clinical Trial Registration
sec.p: URL: https://www.clinicaltrials.gov. Identifier: NCT00106327.

award-group.funding-source: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

list-item.p: Among people with lowerâextremity peripheral artery disease, 6âminute walk distance significantly declined during the 6âmonths following completion of a supervised treadmill exercise intervention.
Supervised treadmill exercise did not have a durable effect on improving walking endurance, measured by 6âminute walk distance, in people with peripheral artery disease.
Supervised treadmill exercise may not have a durable benefit in people with peripheral artery disease.
Additional medical interventions may be necessary to achieve sustained improvement in walking endurance after supervised treadmill exercise in people with peripheral artery disease.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Supervised treadmill exercise significantly improves walking endurance in people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).1, 2, 3, 4 In 2017 Medicare announced a decision to cover 12Â weeks of supervised treadmill exercise for patients with symptomatic PAD.5 In providing this coverage, Medicare assumed that 12Â weeks of supervised treadmill exercise would have a durable benefit for patients with PAD, even after the supervised exercise therapy was completed.5 However, relatively few data exist regarding the durability of benefit from supervised treadmill exercise for patients with PAD.

SILC (the Study to Improve Leg Circulation) was a randomized trial of 6Â months of supervised treadmill exercise and supervised resistance training in people with PAD.3 SILC demonstrated that supervised treadmill exercise, but not supervised resistance training, significantly improved the 6âminute walk at 6âmonth followâup, compared with a control group.3 The current report describes changes in 6âminute walk and other study outcomes at 12âmonth followâup, 6Â months after the exercise interventions were completed. The tested hypothesis was that, in people with PAD, the 6âmonth supervised treadmill exercise intervention would have a durable effect on 6âminute walk performance and the short physical performance battery (SPPB) at 12âmonth followâup, 6Â months after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention was completed.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The institutional review boards of participating sites approved the protocol. Participants gave written informed consent. The study design was a randomized clinical trial.3, 6 Participants were randomized to 1 of 3 groups: supervised treadmill exercise, supervised lower extremity resistance training, or an attention control group.3, 6 Data collection and study interventions were performed at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine between April 1, 2004 and August 19, 2008. The data supporting the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request, within constraints allowed by the institutional review board.

sec.title: Participant Identification
sec.p: Participants were recruited from newspaper and radio advertisements, noninvasive vascular laboratories and clinics at Chicagoâarea hospitals, mailings to Chicago residents aged 60 and older, posted flyers, recruitment mailings to people identified with a low ankleâbrachial index (ABI) in the Lifeline of Screening program, and community outreach methods.6

sec.title: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
sec.p: The inclusion criterion was an ABI â¤0.95.3, 7 Because most people with PAD do not have classical symptoms of intermittent claudication,8, 9, 10 PAD participants without classical intermittent claudication were included to increase generalizability of results.

Exclusion criteria were dementia, critical limb ischemia, foot ulcers, major amputation, nursing home residence, inability to attend exercise sessions 3 times weekly, inability to walk on a treadmill, failure to complete exercise runâin sessions, major surgery, a myocardial infarction within the past 3Â months, major surgery planned in the next year, current participation in other clinical trials, already exercising at a level comparable to that offered in either exercise arm, abnormal baseline exercise stress test, walking limitation from a cause other than PAD, poorly controlled hypertension, and a baseline SPPB score of 12 (ie, maximal possible score).

sec.title: Ankle Brachial Index Measurement
sec.p: A handâheld Doppler probe (Nicolet Vascular Pocket Dop II; Nicolet Biomedical Inc, Golden, CO) was used to obtain systolic pressures in the right and left brachial, dorsalis pedis, and posterior tibial arteries.7, 11, 12 Each pressure was measured twice. The ABI was calculated by dividing the mean of the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pressures in each leg byÂ the mean of the 4 brachial pressures.11 Average pressures in the arm with the higher pressure were used when 1 brachial pressure was higher than the opposite brachial pressure in both measurement sets and the 2 brachial pressures differed by â¥10Â mmÂ Hg in 1 measurement set.11, 12

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: Outcomes were measured at baseline and at 6âmonth and 12âmonth followâup after randomization. Outcome assessors were blinded to participantsâ group assignments. Change in the 6âminute walk test and the SPPB at 6âmonth followâup were the primary outcomes.3, 13, 14, 15 Physical activity, measured by Caltrac accelerometer, was a secondary outcome.16, 17, 18 Exploratory outcomes were the Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ) and the ShortâForm 36 (SFâ36) physical functioning score.19, 20

sec.title: SixâMinute Walk
sec.p: The 6âminute walk test is a wellâvalidated measure of walking endurance in people with PAD that is similar to the type of corridor walking required in daily life.13 The 6âminute walk test was the primary outcome for the following reasons. First, because the 6âminute walk is performed in a hall corridor, it is directly relevant to the type of walking that people with PAD engage in during daily life.13 In contrast, treadmill walking is performed on a moving belt and does not represent the type of walking typically encountered in daily life. Second, among people with PAD, 6âminute walk performance correlates better with physical activity during life than treadmill walking performance.15 Third, treadmill walking performance, but not the 6âminute walk, is associated with a significant learning effect.13 Fourth, a minimum clinically important difference has been defined for the 6âminute walk test,21 but it has not been defined for treadmillâwalking performance.13 Fifth, the 6âminute walk is well validated in people with PAD and predicts mobility loss and mortality.22, 23 Greater decline in the 6âminute walk predicts higher rates of mobility loss and mortality.24 Sixth, 6âminute walk performance correlates with PAD severity.25 Seventh, 6âminute walk distance improves in response to supervised treadmill exercise interventions and in response to homeâbased walking interventions in PAD.3, 4, 26 Because the SILC randomized trial tested a treadmill exercise intervention, and the treadmillâwalking measurement is known to have a learning effect that may be exaggerated by the treadmill intervention, the 6âminute walk test was selected as the primary outcome to avoid a learning effect for the outcome of walking endurance.

Following a standardized protocol,3, 4, 13, 15 participants walked up and down a 100âfoot hallway for 6Â minutes after standardized instructions to cover as much distance as possible. Participants were allowed to rest if needed, but the stopwatch continued during rest periods. The distance completed after 6âminutes was recorded. The intraclass correlation coefficient for testâretest reliability of the 6âminute walk was 0.90 (P<0.001) among 155 PAD participants in our laboratory who completed 2 tests 1 to 2Â weeks apart.13, 15

sec.title: Short Physical Performance Battery
sec.p: The SPPB combined data from the usual paced 4âm walking velocity, time to rise from a seated position 5 times, and standing balance.3, 14 Individuals received a 0 score for each task they were unable to complete. Scores of 1 to 4 were assigned for the remaining tasks, according to established methods.3, 14 Scores were summed to obtain the SPPB, ranging from 0 to 12.3, 14 The testâretest reliability of the SPPB was 0.77 (P<0.001) among 151 PAD participants in our laboratory who completed 2 tests 1 to 2Â weeks apart.3

sec.title: Repeated Chair Rises
sec.p: Participants stood from a seated position in a straightâbacked chair 5 times as quickly as possible without using their arms. Time to complete 5 chair rises was measured.3, 14

sec.title: Standing Balance
sec.p: Participants were asked to hold 3 increasingly difficult standing positions for 10Â seconds each: the sideâbyâside stand, semitandem stand (feet parallel and heel of 1 foot touching the base of the first toe of the opposite foot), and the full tandem stand (standing with 1 foot directly in front of the other).3, 14 Scores ranged from 0 (unable to hold the sideâbyâside stand for 10Â seconds) to 4 (able to hold the full tandem stand for 10Â seconds).

sec.title: FourâMeter Walking Velocity
sec.p: Walking velocity was measured with a 4âm walk performed atÂ the usual pace, according to previously described methods.3, 14

sec.title: Physical Activity
sec.p: Physical activity was measured continuously for 7Â days using a vertical accelerometer (Caltrac, Muscle Dynamics Fitness Network, Inc, Torrance, CA) according to established methods, yielding âactivity units.â16, 17, 18

sec.title: Quality of Life
sec.p: The WIQ is a PADâspecific measure of selfâreported walking limitations with 3 domains: walking distance, walking speed, and stair climbing.19 Each domain is scored on a 0âtoâ100 scale on which 0 represents the most extreme limitation and 100 represents no difficulty walking long distances, walking rapidly, or climbing 3 stair flights, respectively.19 We used the Medical Outcomes Study SFâ36 to assess functional status in the physical functioning domain.20

sec.title: Randomization
sec.p: Eligible participants were randomized using block randomization with block size randomly chosen from 6 and 9. Randomization was stratified by the presence versus absence of intermittent claudication.

sec.title: Interventions
sec.p: During months 1â6, participants attended onâsite sessions. During months 7â12, no onâsite sessions were provided, and all contact with participants was by telephone. Content of the telephone calls varied according to group assignment as described below. All participants were telephoned once per week during month 1, every other week during months 2â3, and once per month in months 4â6.

sec.title: Supervised Treadmill Exercise
sec.p: The supervised treadmill exercise intervention consisted of treadmill exercise 3 times weekly for 6Â months, supervised by an exercise physiologist. Participants began with 15Â minutes of exercise and increased to 40Â minutes of exercise per session.3 After week 8, exercise intensity was increased at least weekly either by increasing treadmill speed or by increasing treadmill grade. Participants were encouraged to exercise to nearâmaximal leg symptoms.

Between months 6 and 12, participants were telephoned by the exercise physiologist and encouraged to continue walking exercise. During this phase of the study, supervised sessions were not available, and exercise recommendations were individualized. Participants with access to a treadmill were encouraged to use the treadmill for exercise. Participants without access to a treadmill were encouraged to walk for exercise outside or at another venue, according to their preferences.

sec.title: Supervised LowerâExtremity Resistance Training
sec.p: Participants in the lowerâextremity resistanceâtraining group exercised 3 times weekly for 6Â months with a trainer. Participants performed 3 sets of 8 repetitions of kneeâextension, legâpress, and legâcurl exercises using standard equipment. For each exercise, the 1 repetition maximum was measured at baseline and subsequently every 4Â weeks. Participants began exercising at 50% of their 1 repetition maximum and increased to 80% of their 1 repetition maximum during the first 5Â weeks of exercise training. Weights were adjusted after each monthly 1 repetition maximum and as needed to achieve an exercise intensity consistent with a rate of perceived exertion of 12 to 14. Participants also performed 3 sets of 8 repetitions of squat and toeârise exercises.
Between months 6 and 12, participants were provided with ankle weights and instructed on lower extremity resistance exercises with the ankle weights to perform at home.

sec.title: Attention Control, Months 1 to 6
sec.p: The attentionâcontrol group was designed to ensure that participants not randomized to exercise received regular attention from study staff. The attention control group attended 11 1âhour group sessions over a 6âmonth period, during which a registered dietician provided information regarding nutritional supplements, healthy restaurant eating, and increasing fruit and vegetable consumption. During months 6 to 12, participants were telephoned by the registered dietician, and nutrition information previously provided during onâsite sessions was reviewed.

sec.title: Leg Symptoms
sec.p: Leg symptoms were characterized using the San Diego claudication questionnaire.9, 27 Based on prior study, intermittent claudication was defined as exertional calf pain that did not begin at rest, caused the participant to stop walking, and resolved within 10Â minutes of rest.9, 27 Participants without intermittent claudication were classified either as asymptomatic if they had no exertional leg symptoms or with atypical ischemic leg symptoms if they had exertional leg symptoms not consistent with intermittent claudication (9.27).

sec.title: Additional Measures
sec.p: Medical history, race, and demographics were obtained using a standardized data collection form. Body mass index was calculated based on height and weight measures obtained at the study visit.

sec.title: Power Considerations
sec.p: The a priori sample size calculation was as follows. At 12âmonth followâup, 6Â months after the supervised interventions were completed, a sample size of 50 participants in each group provided 80% power to detect a difference of 30.2Â m in mean change of 6âminute walk distance and a difference of 0.97 in mean change in the SPPB score between each exercise group and the control group. For the 6âminute walk, a small meaningful difference consists of 20Â m, and a large meaningful difference consists of 50Â m.21 For the SPPB, a small meaningful difference consists of 0.50 point and a large meaningful difference consists of 1.0 point.21

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Intentionâtoâtreat analyses were performed. Chiâsquared tests, Fisher exact test, and 1âway analyses of variance were used to compare characteristics of participants across the 3 groups at baseline. For the outcomes of 6âminute walk, SPPB, and Caltrac physical activity, 2âsample, 2âsided t tests were used to compare changes in outcomes between baseline and 6âmonth followâup, between 6â and 12âmonth followâup, and between baseline and 12âmonth followâup between each exercise group and the control group, respectively. Because distributions of remaining outcomes (ie, WIQ scores) were skewed, median values and interquartile ranges were used to summarize crossâsectional distributions and changes for remaining outcomes. The betweenâgroup comparisons for these outcomes were based on 2âsided HodgeâLehman tests, which did not require the normal assumption. The withinâgroup change was evaluated using a 1âsample Wilcoxon rank test. Missing data were imputed for participants who attended a 12âmonth followâup visit but were missing data for at least 1 outcome at any of the visits, using multiple imputation (SAS Proc MI; SAS Institute, Cary, NC) and generating 20 imputed data sets. Variables used for imputation were treatment assignment, age, ABI, body mass index, sex, race, smoking status, leg symptoms, comorbidities, and study outcomes at baseline, 6âmonth followâup, and 12âmonth followâup. Corresponding comparisons between groups were based on 2âsample, 2âsided t tests or HodgeâLehman tests, based on the imputed data sets. A priori, the P value considered statistically significant was P<0.05. Analyses were performed using SAS version 9.4.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of 156 participants with PAD randomized, 144 (92%) completed 6âmonth followâup testing, and 134 (86%) completed 12âmonth followâup testing (FigureÂ 1). Participants who did not complete 12âmonth followâup testing had higher prevalences of heart failure and current smoking compared with those who completed 12âmonth followâup testing (TableÂ 1).

caption.p: Characteristics of Participants With Versus Without 12âMonth FollowâUp Data

sec.p: Among participants who completed 12âmonth followâup testing, the mean age of participants was 70.7 (SD=10.4), 61 (46%) were male, and 53 (40%) were black; mean ABI was 0.61 (SD=0.17). The prevalence of blacks was lowest among participants randomized to strength training and highest among participants randomized to the control group. There were no other differences in characteristics across the 3 groups (TableÂ 2). Although rates of successful telephone contact between the exercise physiologist and the participant were not systematically tracked, the proportions of successfully completed monthly telephone calls to ascertain serious adverse events were 86.9% in the treadmillâexercise group, 84.5% in the strengthâtrained group, and 83.7% in the control group.

caption.p: Baseline Characteristics According to Group Assignment*

tr.td: Asymptomatic, no exertional leg symptoms, n (%)
Physical activity over 7Â days (activity units), mean SD

fn.p: Missing data were imputed for individuals who attended a 12âmonth followâup visit but did not complete all outcomes at a study visit. IQR indicates interquartile range (25th, 75th percentiles); WIQ, Walking Impairment Questionnaire.
Data shown in TableÂ 2 are for all participants who participated in 12âmonth followâup testing for at least 1 outcome measure.

sec.p: The 6âmonth supervised treadmill exercise intervention significantly improved the 6âminute walk distance at 6âmonth followâup, compared with control (+36.1Â m, 95%CI +13.9â58.3, P=0.001). However, at 12âmonth followâup, 6Â months after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention had been completed, there was no difference in change in 6âminute walk distance from baseline between people randomized to supervised treadmill exercise and those randomized to the control group (+7.5Â m, 95%CI â17.5 to +32.6, P=0.56) (TableÂ 3). During the 6 months after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention had been completed, between 6â and 12âmonth followâup, the 6âminute walk significantly declined in the treadmill exercise group (withinâgroup change â24.6Â m, 95%CI â41.2 to â8.0, P=0.004; betweenâgroup change compared with the control group was â28.6Â m, 95%CI â52.6 to â4.5, P=0.020) (TableÂ 4, FigureÂ 2). There was no effect of the supervised treadmill exercise intervention on change in the SPPB at any followâup time point (TablesÂ 3 and 4).

caption.p: 12âMonth Change in Study Outcomes After a 6âMonth Supervised Exercise Intervention

tr.th: 12âMo Change Compared to the AttentionâControl Group

fn.p: Median and interquartile ranges are shown. Estimate (95%CI) and P value are from the combined results for HodgesâLehmann Estimation. Missing data were imputed for individuals who attended a 12âmonth followâup visit but did not complete all outcomes at a study visit.

caption.p: Changes From Baseline at 6â and 12âMonth FollowâUp in Study Outcomes by Group Assignment Among Participants With Peripheral Artery Disease

tr.th: 6 to 12Â Mo Change Relative to Control

fn.p: Median and interquartile ranges are shown. Estimate (95%CI) and P value are from the combined results for HodgesâLehmann Estimation. Data were imputed for individuals who attended a 12âmonth followâup visit but did not complete all outcome measures at each visit.

caption.p: Change over time in 6âminute walk and the short physical performance battery after a 6âmonth supervised treadmill exercise intervention in peripheral artery disease (N=134). A, 6âminute walk distance. B, Short physical performance battery (SPPB) scores.

sec.p: The supervised treadmill exercise intervention significantly improved the WIQ distance score at 6âmonth followâup (medianâ+15.0, 95%CI, +6.1 to +23.9, P=0.001). However, at 12âmonth followâup, 6Â months after completion of the treadmill exercise intervention, there were no significant effects of the treadmill exercise intervention on any WIQ scores compared to the control group (TableÂ 3). During the 6 months after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention had been completed, between 6â and 12âmonth followâup, the WIQ distance score declined in the treadmill exercise group compared with the control group, but the difference did not quite reach statistical significance (â8.8, 95%CI â18.3 to +0.6, P=0.066) (TableÂ 4).

The 6âmonth supervised treadmill exercise intervention improved the SFâ36 physical functioning score at 12âmonth followâup (+10.0, 95%CI +0.7 to 19.3, P=0.035) compared with the control group (TableÂ 3). The supervised exercise intervention did not improve physical activity at 12âmonth followâup, compared with the control group (TableÂ 3).
There were no significant effects of the resistance training intervention on any study outcome at 12âmonth followâup.

Results did not substantially change when the 8 participants (5.9%) who had reported no exertional leg symptoms at baseline (ie, asymptomatic participants) were excluded from analyses (data not shown). However, after exclusion of the 8 PAD participants who were asymptomatic, compared with control, physical activity levels significantly declined between 6â and 12âmonth followâup in those randomized to supervised treadmill exercise (â285Â m, 95%CI â570 to â1, P=0.0496). Results were largely unchanged when analyses were performed separately among participants with intermittent claudication and among those without intermittent claudication symptoms. However, among participants with intermittent claudication, the difference between the supervised treadmill exercise group and controls in decline in 6âminute walk distance between 6â and 12âmonth followâup was no longer statistically significant (â21.6Â m, 95%CI â58.6 to +15.4), perhaps due to the small sample size in this group (N=49). In addition, among participants without classical symptoms of intermittent claudication, there was no difference in the SFâ36 physical functioning score between the supervised treadmill exercise and control groups at 12âmonth followâup (+6.3, 95%CI â6.2 to +18.7, P=0.32), and the WIQ distance score declined significantly in the supervised treadmill exercise group compared with controls between 6â and 12âmonth followâup (â12.4, 95%CI â24.4 to â0.5, P=0.042).
Nonimputed results for data in TablesÂ 3 and 4 are shown in Tables S1 and S2.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the primary results for this randomized clinical trial of participants with PAD, 6Â months of supervised treadmill exercise significantly improved the 6âminute walk distance at 6âmonth followâup compared with a control group.3 However, the 6âminute walk distance significantly declined during the 6Â months after supervised exercise had ended. Twelve months after baseline (6Â months after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention had been completed), there was no significant difference in change in the 6âminute walk distance from baseline between PAD participants randomized to supervised treadmill exercise and those randomized to control. These results demonstrated that supervised treadmill exercise did not have a durable benefit on a 6âminute walk distance in people with PAD.

To our knowledge, this is the only trial to study whether the beneficial effect of supervised treadmill exercise on the 6âminute walk distance in people with PAD is durable after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention has been completed. However, prior studies have suggested that supervised treadmill exercise had a persistent benefit on treadmillâwalking performance. The CLEVER (Claudication: Exercise vs. Endoluminal Revascularization Study) trial randomized 111 participants with PAD and aortoiliac disease to either supervised treadmill exercise for 6Â months, endovascular revascularization with stenting, or neither therapy.28, 29 At 6âmonth followâup, supervised treadmill exercise and revascularization each improved treadmill walking performance more than control paticipants (withinâgroup mean change from baseline: +5.8Â minutes [SD=4.6], +3.7Â minutes [SD=4.9], and +1.2Â minutes [SD=2.6], respectively).28 Between a 6â and 18âmonth followâup, participants in the treadmill exercise group received telephone calls encouraging exercise but were not supervised. Among the 79 (71%) of the randomized participants who completed 18âmonth followâup measures, treadmill walking time remained significantly better in the supervised treadmill exercise group and in the revascularization group compared with controls (+5.0Â minutes [SD=5.4], +3.2Â minutes [SD=4.7], +0.2Â minutes [SD=2.1], respectively).29 A separate study reported that 4Â years after completing a supervised treadmill exercise intervention, few patients with PAD continued to exercise and that those who stopped exercising experienced the greatest decline in treadmill walking ability.30 However, this study was limited by a 50% dropout rate. The outcome measure in these prior trials was treadmillâwalking performance, which is associated with a learning effect. Therefore, it is possible that the persistent improvement in treadmillâwalking performance may be due to a learning effect rather than a true longâterm benefit in walking endurance.13 In contrast, the 6âminute walk test is not associated with a learning effect.13 Therefore, persistent improvement in the 6âminute walk is more likely to represent a meaningful persistent improvement in walking endurance. The lack of persistent benefit in 6âminute walk performance is important because the corridor walking measured during the 6âminute walk test is more relevant to walking during daily life.13

The WIQ distance score significantly improved in the supervised treadmill group at 6âmonth followâup, but this effect did not persist at 12âmonth followâup. However, the SFâ36 physical functioning score was significantly better in the supervised treadmill exercise group compared with the control group at 12âmonth followâup, suggesting that those randomized to supervised treadmill exercise perceived benefit at 12âmonth followâup, even though their 6âminute walk distance was not better at 12âmonth followâup compared to the control group.

In contrast to findings reported here for the 6âminute walk, a previous study showed that a homeâbased walking exercise intervention had a durable benefit on change in 6âminute walk distance in people with PAD.30 The GOALS (Group Oriented Arterial Leg Study) trial randomized 194 participants with PAD to a groupâmediated cognitive behavioral intervention designed to encourage homeâbased exercise, versus an attention control group.30 After 6âmonths of weekly onâsite meetings with the study coach and other participants with PAD, the 6âminute walk distance significantly improved by 53.5Â m in the intervention group, relative to the control group.30 Between 6â and 12âmonth followâup, PAD participants received only telephone calls encouraging them to continue exercise. At 12âmonth followâup, participants randomized to exercise continued to have a significantly greater improvement from baseline in 6âminute walk distance by +34.1Â m 6Â months after the intensive phase of the intervention had been completed, relative to the control group.30

There are several potential explanations for why supervised treadmill exercise did not have a sustained benefit on improving the 6âminute walk distance in people with PAD. First, supervised treadmill exercise has a more potent effect on improving treadmillâwalking distance than on improving the 6âminute walk distance.3, 4, 13, 31, 32 In people with PAD, supervised treadmill exercise improves the 6âminute walk by 31Â m compared with a nonexercising control group, whereas homeâbased exercise improves the 6âminute walk by 50 to 55Â m compared with a nonexercising control group.3, 4, 31, 32 This less potent effect of supervised treadmill exercise on change in 6âminute walk distance may result in a less durable benefit of supervised treadmill exercise on change in 6âminute walk. Second, supervised treadmill exercise is difficult for many PAD patients to continue once the supervised treadmill exercise intervention is completed. Third, supervised treadmill exercise improves treadmillâwalking performance in part because of a learning effect,13 and this learning effect may be durable, resulting in a persistently improved treadmillâwalking distance, even after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention has been completed. In contrast, supervised treadmill exercise does not confer a learning effect on the 6âminute walk test. Therefore, a 6âminute walk distance may be a more direct measure of walking endurance, which may decline after supervised treadmill exercise is completed. Findings reported here are consistent with prior data suggesting that 6âminute walk performance and treadmillâwalking performance should not be considered interchangeable measures of walking endurance in people with PAD.33 Fourth, a decline in physical activity level observed in the supervised treadmill exercise group between 6â and 12âmonth followâup that was nearly statistically significant compared with the control group may have contributed to the decline in the 6âminute walk distance observed in this group after the supervised treadmill exercise intervention ended.

This study has limitations. First, this trial did not repeat treadmill exercise testing at 12âmonth followâup. Therefore, it could not determine whether the improvement in treadmillâwalking performance observed at the 6âmonth followâup was maintained at 12Â months.3 Second, 10 participants who completed a 6âmonth followâup did not complete the 12âmonth followâup testing. However, data were imputed for the participants who provided data for at least one 12âmonth followâup measure.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A supervised treadmill exercise intervention that significantly improved the 6âminute walk distance at a 6âmonth followâup3 did not have a durable benefit on that 6âminute walk performance 6Â months after the treadmill exercise intervention was completed. These results do not support a persistent beneficial effect of supervised treadmill exercise on the 6âminute walk distance in patients with PAD.

sec.title: Sources of Funding
sec.p: This work was funded by the National Heart Lung and Blood Institute (R01âHL73351, R01âHL122846, and R01âHL126117), the intramural program of the National Institute on Aging, and the Jesse Brown VA Medical Center.

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: Dr McDermott reports receipt of research support from Hershey's Company, ReserveAge, Chromadex, Regeneron, and ViroMed. The remaining authors have no disclosures to report.
